issue.title: Exception when reflecting tables with SQL Server 2005

labels.name: reflection
labels.description: reflection of tables, columns, constraints, defaults, sequences, views, everything else

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

Reflecting a table's columns using a combination of the Microsoft ODBC SQL Server drivers with SQL Server 2005 raises an exception. 

**Expected behavior**
I would expect to get a list of columns in the table with no exception (which happens with the FreeTDS driver).

**To Reproduce**

```py
from sqlalchemy import create_engine, inspect

source_engine = create_engine("mssql+pyodbc:///?odbc_connect=[OMITTED]")

insp = inspect(source_engine)
insp.get_columns('TABLE NAME', schema='SCHEMA NAME')
```

**Error**

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 1276, in _execute_context
    self.dialect.do_execute(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\default.py", line 593, in do_execute
    cursor.execute(statement, parameters)
pyodbc.ProgrammingError: ('42000', "[42000] [Microsoft][ODBC SQL Server Driver][SQL Server]Incorrect syntax near 'sp_columns'. (102) (SQLExecDirectW); [42000] [Microsoft][ODBC SQL Server Driver][SQL Server]Statement(s) could not be prepared. (8180)")

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\reflection.py", line 390, in get_columns
    col_defs = self.dialect.get_columns(
  File "<string>", line 2, in get_columns
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\reflection.py", line 52, in cache
    ret = fn(self, con, *args, **kw)
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\dialects\mssql\base.py", line 2195, in wrap
    return _switch_db(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\dialects\mssql\base.py", line 2219, in _switch_db
    return fn(*arg, **kw)
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\dialects\mssql\base.py", line 2741, in get_columns
    cursor = connection.execute(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 2235, in execute
    return connection.execute(statement, *multiparams, **params)
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 1011, in execute
    return meth(self, multiparams, params)
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\sql\elements.py", line 298, in _execute_on_connection
    return connection._execute_clauseelement(self, multiparams, params)
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 1124, in _execute_clauseelement
    ret = self._execute_context(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 1316, in _execute_context
    self._handle_dbapi_exception(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 1510, in _handle_dbapi_exception
    util.raise_(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\util\compat.py", line 182, in raise_
    raise exception
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\base.py", line 1276, in _execute_context
    self.dialect.do_execute(
  File "C:\somewhere\miniconda3\envs\migration\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\default.py", line 593, in do_execute
    cursor.execute(statement, parameters)
sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (pyodbc.ProgrammingError) ('42000', "[42000] [Microsoft][ODBC SQL Server Driver][SQL Server]Incorrect syntax near 'sp_columns'. (102) (SQLExecDirectW); [42000] [Microsoft][ODBC SQL Server Driver][SQL Server]Statement(s) could not be prepared. (8180)")
[SQL: sp_columns @table_name = ?, @table_owner = ?]
[parameters: ('XXX', 'YYY')]
(Background on this error at: http://sqlalche.me/e/13/f405)
```

**Versions.**
 - OS: Windows 10 [& Debian 10 in docker image on a RedHat 7 host]
 - Python: 3.9
 - SQLAlchemy: 1.3.21
 - Database: Microsoft SQL Server 2005 - 9.00.1399.06 (Intel X86) 
 - DBAPI: pyodbc 4.0.30
 - Drivers: 
    - SQL Server 10.00.14393.00
    - SQL Server Native Client 11.0 2011.110.7462.06
    - ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server 2017.174.01.01

**Additional context**
This bug doesn't happen with the FreeTDS Linux driver, or with never versions of SQL Server.

The way the expression is written matters. Using the implicit `EXEC` (as in the library) 
```py
rs = source_engine.execute("sp_columns @table_name = ?, @table_owner = ?", ('XXX', 'YYY'))
```
raises the exception seen above. However, using `EXEC` explicitly results in the correct behaviour (and should also be compatible with later SQL Server versions that do support the implicit form).
```py
rs = source_engine.execute("EXEC sp_columns @table_name = ?, @table_owner = ?", ('XXX', 'YYY'))
rs.fetchone()
```

**Have a nice day!**

body:
According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft_SQL_Server), the history of SQL Server 2005 was:

Release Date: 14 January 2005 — 16.1 years ago
Mainstream End Date: 12 April 2011 — 9.8 years ago
Extended End Date: 12 April 2016 — 4.8 years ago

IMO, an app running against a backend that old can just pin their version of SQLAlchemy to 1.3.x.

I have no particular preference one way or the other. On the other end we are still supporting oracle 8 that was released in 1997 :)

The filter fix should be easy to do. Or if we drop support we should update docs / code etc.

I went through the public inspector API and the only query that failed was `get_indexes` which was trying to use a non-existent column. 

The only other two "failures" were that `get_check_constraints` and `get_unique_constraints` raised Not Implemented exceptions, which seemed strange because that wasn't mentioned in the docs (in contrast to other methods where it was). 

Oracle 8 is certainly older! SQL Server is widespread enough that surely I'm not the only person who still needs to sometimes use the 2005 version of it? (I am really hoping that I'm not just the one weirdo user who wants something that no one else will ever use).

rename.to: Feasibility of support for mssql 2005/2008 in 1.4

body:
As for SQL Server 2008 (whose Extended Support ended 18 months ago), version 1.4 is not too happy with it, either.

[sqla_14_mssql_2008.txt](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/files/5951554/sqla_14_mssql_2008.txt)

Maybe we could restrict the scope here to just making that get index call pass.

Not having those db available for the CI will inevitably lead to new incompatibilities to be introduced, so even if we make all test pass at this point in time, there is no guarantee that they will not break again in the future

Okay, I just ran `tox -e py37-mssql-backendonly` for 1.4 against a SQL Server 2012 Express instance. We hit the 25 failure/error limit with this one too. The difference is that while the 2008 errors were mainly

> Invalid object name 'INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SEQUENCES'

the 2012 errors were primarily 

> 'JSON_VALUE' is not a recognized built-in function name

Since these older versions will almost certainly never be part of CI testing I don't see any point in messing around with the tests to get them to skip. Instead, I suggest that we treat those older versions as either "unsupported" or "best effort" and if issues arise then fix them if we can (like #5921).

I propose

|   | SQLA 1.3 | SQLA 1.4 | SQLA 2.0 |
| - | --------- | ---------- | --------- |
| MSSQL 2000 and earlier | unsupported | unsupported | unsupported |
| MSSQL 2005 | best effort | unsupported¹ | unsupported |
| MSSQL 2008² | best effort | best effort | unsupported |
| MSSQL 2012 | supported | supported | we'll see …³ |
| MSSQL 2014 and newer | supported | supported | supported |

¹ known issues in 1.4 (like the reflection error that originally prompted this issue) → won't fix
² Extended Support end date: 9 July 2019
³ Extended Support end date: 12 July 2022 

Also, when we update the docs we should note that practically speaking the oldest version we can support in CI is SQL Server 2017 (the first version available for Linux).

I mostly agree Gord.

Regarding this reflection issue, the patch is very easy to do:
```diff
diff --git a/lib/sqlalchemy/dialects/mssql/base.py b/lib/sqlalchemy/dialects/mssql/base.py
index 674d54179..c0318e374 100644
--- a/lib/sqlalchemy/dialects/mssql/base.py
+++ b/lib/sqlalchemy/dialects/mssql/base.py
@@ -2894,16 +2894,22 @@ class MSDialect(default.DefaultDialect):
     @reflection.cache
     @_db_plus_owner
     def get_indexes(self, connection, tablename, dbname, owner, schema, **kw):
+        filter_definition = (
+            "ind.filter_definition"
+            if self.version_info >= MS_2008_VERSION
+            else "NULL as filter_definition"
+        )
         rp = connection.execution_options(future_result=True).execute(
             sql.text(
                 "select ind.index_id, ind.is_unique, ind.name, "
-                "ind.filter_definition "
+                "%s "
                 "from sys.indexes as ind join sys.tables as tab on "
                 "ind.object_id=tab.object_id "
                 "join sys.schemas as sch on sch.schema_id=tab.schema_id "
                 "where tab.name = :tabname "
                 "and sch.name=:schname "
                 "and ind.is_primary_key=0 and ind.type != 0"
+                % filter_definition
             )
             .bindparams(
                 sql.bindparam("tabname", tablename, ischema.CoerceUnicode()),
```

**Federico Caselli** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **master** branch:

**Add supported database version for internal dialects** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2585

**Federico Caselli** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **master** branch:

**Fix a reflection error for MSSQL 2005** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2594
